discussion.content: Although High Gain could be a viable answer, given the information D would be the logical answer. Please let me know if I am incorrect.

In order to answer this question correctly, ideally a survey of the campus needs to be analysed before an appropriate action can be implemented (ie the most cost-effective and efficient method to provide wireless coverage).

Answer A can be the correct answer, but High Gain (HGA - High Gain Antenna) ma not be the ideal answer as this technology has specific requirements such as the need of open spaces so that there are no hindrances for the directional radio waves. 

The link below provides more information: 

What does High-Gain Antenna (HGA) mean? 
https://www.techopedia.com/definition/26056/high-gain-antenna-hga

If the cafe is located within a building or surrounded by other buildings (ie 'obstacles') then maybe an alternative answer may be deemed more suitable (Answer 'D' > Omni-directional).

But the underlying gist of thyye matter is that the question made here does not warrant a concrete answer due to its vagueness and places the student taking the exam in an unfair position. In a real-life scenario and network engineer would b far have more relevant data at his or her disposal before making an appropriate decision. 

Basically this question has been poorly throughout.

questions.question_text:
A campus needs to provide wireless connectivity in a cafeteria with a minimal number of WAPs.
Which of the following antenna types will provide the BEST coverage?

discussion.content: I'm not contesting the answer but how are you supposed to "implement" a contractual agreement on a service that is already being rendered? Are you gonna call up Commcast and tell them to sign a contract giving you the right to take action against them for service outages? Good luck with that.

A good read if so inclined:

6 tips for drafting better statements of work
https://www.csoonline.com/article/3227830/6-tips-for-drafting-better-statements-of-work.html

Granted, focused primarily on SOW, but the underling work ethic should encompass all types of contractual obligations.

questions.question_text:
A small office has an Internet connection that drops out about two times per week. It often takes until the next day for the vendor to come out and fix the issue.
Which of the following should the office implement to reduce this downtime?

A technician installs three new switches to a companys infrastructure. The network technician notices that all the switch port lights on the front of each switch flashes rapidly when powered on and connected. Additionally, there are rapid flashing amber lights on the switches when they started up the next day.
Which of the following describes what is occurring with the switches?

choices.D: The switches are not functioning properly and need to be disconnected.
choices.B: The switches are having problems communicating with each other.
choices.C: The switches are connected and detected a spanning tree loop.
choices.A: The switches are running through their spanning tree process.

discussion.content:
Answer 'A' is correct. 

As per link below for those wanting to get more out of the question:

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/lan/catalyst3750/hardware/installation/guide/3750hig/HIGOVERV.html#wp1136573

Specifically:

Table 1-6 Meaning of LED Colors in Different Modes on the Switch 

'STAT(port status) > Blinking amber : Port is blocked by STP and is sending and receiving packets.'
I think, the best Answer should be D, from the given choices. By matching a MAC address to an IP address within the DHCP scope D

questions.question_text: How does a DHCP reservation work?

choices.D: By matching a MAC address to an IP address within the DHCP scope D
choices.B: By letting the network switches assign IP addresses from a reserved pool
choices.A: By leasing a set of reserved IP addresses according to their category.
choices.C: By assigning options to the computers on the network by priority

discussion.content:
I personally would also add '-s' in the 'Netstat -p' syntax.

...as in 'netstat -p -s' 

'Netstat -s'

'Displays per-protocol statistics. By default, statistics are shown for IP, IPv6, ICMP, ICMPv6, TCP, TCPv6, UDP, and UDPv6; the -p option may be used to specify a subset of the default.'

More can be learned here:

MS-DOS and Windows command line netstat command
https://www.computerhope.com/netstat.htm
